title: Appending Permutations (Easy Version)
statementHtml:
This is the easy version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, n≤100n≤100. You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem.

You are given an initially empty array aa. You may perform the following operation any number of times:

[r,r+1,…,s,1,2,…,r−1][r,r+1,…,s,1,2,…,r−1]

to the end of aa.

Your task is to count the number of distinct arrays of length exactly nn that can be constructed using the allowed operation and satisfy all of the given restrictions. Two arrays are considered different if they differ at any position from 11 to nn.

Print the answer modulo 998244353998244353.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (1≤n≤100,0≤m≤min(5000,n2)1≤n≤100,0≤m≤min(5000,n2)) — denoting the length of the array aa and the number of restrictions.

The following mm lines each contain two integers ii and xx (1≤i,x≤n1≤i,x≤n), indicating that ai≠xai≠x is a requirement of the final array. It is guaranteed that no limitation is given more than once.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 100100, and the sum of mm over all test cases does not exceed 50005000.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the number of arrays modulo 998244353998244353.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, there are 77 total attainable arrays: [1,2,3],[2,3,1],[3,1,2],[1,1,2],[1,2,1],[2,1,1],[1,1,1][1,2,3],[2,3,1],[3,1,2],[1,1,2],[1,2,1],[2,1,1],[1,1,1].

In the second test case, none of the above 77 are valid because no element is allowed to be 11, and all of the arrays have at least one 11.

In the third case, only [2,3,1][2,3,1] is counted.
